source.name: City of Boston Public Works Department
source.notes: Based on official City of Boston Public Works recycling guidelines. Single-stream blue bin recycling. Specific neighborhoods can use heavy-duty clear plastic bags.

materials.name: Plastic bottles
instructions: Empty and rinse
Replace cap
Place in blue recycling bin or cart
notes: Boston accepts #1-#7 rigid plastics
commonMistakes: Don't include bottles with liquid still inside

materials.name: Plastic containers
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place in blue recycling bin
notes: Rigid plastic containers accepted in Boston
commonMistakes: Don't include containers with food residue
No styrofoam

materials.name: Cardboard
instructions: Flatten all boxes
Remove packing materials
Place in or beside blue recycling bin
notes: Break down boxes to save space
commonMistakes: Don't include cardboard soaked with grease
Remove styrofoam inserts

materials.name: Paperboard / cereal boxes
instructions: Flatten
Remove plastic liner (trash it)
Place in blue recycling bin
notes: Thin paperboard is recyclable in Boston
commonMistakes: Don't forget to remove plastic liners

materials.name: Paper and newspapers
instructions: Place in blue recycling bin
No need to remove staples or window envelopes
notes: Most clean dry paper is recyclable in Boston
commonMistakes: Don't include paper towels or tissues
Don't bag paper in plastic bags

materials.name: Glass bottles and jars
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place in blue recycling bin
notes: All colors of glass accepted in Boston curbside recycling
commonMistakes: Don't include broken glass; wrap and trash
Don't include window glass, mirrors, or ceramics

materials.name: Metal cans
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place in blue recycling bin
notes: Labels can stay on
Includes aluminum and steel/tin cans
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food residue

materials.name: Aluminum foil
instructions: Clean off all food residue
Ball up foil pieces
Place in blue recycling bin
notes: Must be clean; heavily soiled foil goes in trash
commonMistakes: Don't recycle foil with baked-on food

materials.name: Aerosol cans
instructions: Must be completely empty
Place in blue recycling bin
notes: Non-empty aerosols are hazardous waste
commonMistakes: Don't recycle if can still has pressure

materials.name: Milk / juice cartons
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place in blue recycling bin
notes: Cartons accepted in Boston curbside recycling
commonMistakes: Don't include cartons with liquid still inside

materials.name: Books
instructions: Donate if in good condition
If damaged, place in blue recycling bin
Remove heavily laminated covers and trash them
notes: Boston Public Library accepts book donations
Donating is preferred over recycling
commonMistakes: Don't throw usable books in trash

materials.name: Plastic bags
instructions: Do NOT put in blue recycling bin
Take to grocery stores (Stop & Shop, Star Market, Shaw's) for store drop-off
Otherwise place in trash
Plastic shopping bags cannot be recycled curbside in Boston
notes: Plastic bags jam Boston's recycling machinery
Most grocery stores in Boston accept bags for recycling
commonMistakes: Never bag recyclables in plastic bags
Never put film plastic in the blue bin

materials.name: Black / white trash bags
instructions: Black and white trash bags cannot be used for recycling
Do not use trash bags to hold recyclables
notes: Boston does not allow recyclables in opaque bags
Only heavy-duty clear bags allowed in specific neighborhoods
commonMistakes: Never put recyclables in black or white trash bags

materials.name: Heavy-duty clear plastic bags
instructions: Heavy-duty clear plastic bags allowed ONLY in specific Boston neighborhoods
Eligible neighborhoods: Back Bay/Bay Village, Beacon Hill, Charlestown, Fenway, Mission Hill, North End, Roxbury, South Boston, South End, West End
All other neighborhoods must use a lidded bin
notes: This is a neighborhood-specific exception for dense urban areas without bin storage
Bags must be heavy-duty and transparent
commonMistakes: Don't use clear bags if you're not in an eligible neighborhood
Don't use thin or opaque bags

materials.name: Styrofoam
instructions: Place in trash
Not accepted in Boston recycling
notes: Styrofoam is not recyclable curbside in Boston
commonMistakes: Don't put styrofoam in the blue bin

materials.name: Food waste / food scraps
instructions: Boston has a curbside composting pilot (Project Oscar) for food scraps
If enrolled: place food scraps in provided compost bin
If not enrolled: place in trash or find a community composting site
notes: Project Oscar is Boston's curbside composting pilot program
Check boston.gov for availability in your neighborhood
commonMistakes: Don't put food waste in the blue recycling bin
Check if Project Oscar is available in your area

materials.name: Yard waste
instructions: Place in paper bags or open barrels labeled 'yard waste'
Boston collects yard waste during spring and fall seasons
Branches: cut to 3 feet and bundle
Check boston.gov for seasonal collection schedule
notes: Yard waste collection is seasonal in Boston
Do not use plastic bags
commonMistakes: Don't bag yard waste in plastic bags
Don't mix with regular trash

materials.name: Paper plates and napkins
instructions: Place in trash
Food-soiled paper is not recyclable
notes: If enrolled in Project Oscar composting: food-soiled paper may be accepted
commonMistakes: Don't put food-soiled paper in recycling

materials.name: Takeout containers
instructions: Foam containers: trash
Rigid plastic containers: rinse and recycle if clean
Paper containers soiled with food: trash
notes: Only clean rigid plastic containers are recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't put food-soiled containers in recycling

materials.name: Diapers
instructions: Bag and place in trash
notes: Not recyclable or compostable
commonMistakes: Never put diapers in the blue bin

materials.name: Batteries
instructions: Do not put in trash or recycling
Take to Boston Household Hazardous Waste drop-off day
Tape terminals of lithium and 9V batteries
notes: Boston holds HHW collection events
Call 311 for schedule
commonMistakes: Don't throw batteries in trash or recycling

materials.name: Electronics / E-waste
instructions: Take to Boston drop-off center or Best Buy
Massachusetts bans CRTs, TVs, and computers from trash
Delete personal data before disposal
notes: MA has a waste ban on electronics in trash
commonMistakes: Don't put electronics in trash or recycling

materials.name: Paint
instructions: Take to Boston HHW collection day
Latex paint: can dry out with kitty litter and trash the solid
Oil-based paint: must go to HHW
notes: Boston holds HHW days; call 311 or check boston.gov
commonMistakes: Don't pour paint down the drain

materials.name: Motor oil
instructions: Take to Boston HHW collection or auto parts store
AutoZone and O'Reilly accept used oil
notes: Most auto parts stores accept oil for free
commonMistakes: Don't pour down drains

materials.name: Medications
instructions: Take to Boston police drug take-back
CVS and Walgreens participate in take-back programs
If no drop-off: mix with coffee grounds, seal, and trash
notes: BPD and DEA hold drug take-back events
commonMistakes: Don't flush medications

materials.name: Clothing and textiles
instructions: Donate to Goodwill, Salvation Army, or Boston-area thrift stores
Textile recycling bins at various Boston locations
Even worn-out textiles accepted in textile bins
notes: Boston has numerous donation and textile recycling options
commonMistakes: Don't put clothing in the blue recycling bin

materials.name: Light bulbs
instructions: CFL and fluorescent: take to Boston HHW or Home Depot/Lowe's
LED bulbs: e-waste recycling
Incandescent: wrap and trash
notes: CFL bulbs contain mercury
commonMistakes: Don't put CFL or fluorescent bulbs in trash

materials.name: Disposable coffee cups
instructions: Place in trash
Plastic-lined cups are not recyclable
notes: The plastic lining prevents recycling
Plastic lids: recycle in blue bin
commonMistakes: Don't put lined cups in recycling

materials.name: Receipts
instructions: Place in trash
Thermal paper contains BPA
notes: Thermal receipts contaminate recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Candy wrappers
instructions: Place in trash
Multi-layer film not recyclable
notes: Wrappers look metallic but are multi-layer plastic
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Chip bags / snack bags
instructions: Place in trash
notes: Metallized film; not recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Pizza box
instructions: Greasy pizza boxes: place in trash
Clean top half: tear off and recycle in blue bin
notes: Food-soiled cardboard is not accepted in Boston recycling
If enrolled in Project Oscar: greasy portions may go in compost
commonMistakes: Don't put grease-soaked cardboard in the blue bin

materials.name: Bubble wrap / packing materials
instructions: Place in trash
Or take plastic film to store drop-off bins
notes: Plastic film not accepted in Boston curbside recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling bin

materials.name: Cooking oil / grease
instructions: Collect in sealed container
Take to Boston HHW day or restaurant grease recycling
Never pour down the drain
notes: Grease causes sewer blockages
commonMistakes: Don't pour down sink

materials.name: Propane tanks
instructions: Take to Boston HHW collection day
Never put in trash or recycling
notes: Pressurized containers are dangerous
commonMistakes: Never puncture or put in trash

materials.name: Needles / sharps
instructions: Place in puncture-resistant sharps container
Take to Boston HHW event or pharmacy
Boston also accepts sharps at some drop-off locations
notes: Never place loose sharps in trash
commonMistakes: Never put loose sharps in trash or recycling

materials.name: Mattress
instructions: Schedule a bulk item pickup through Boston 311
Or take to a Boston drop-off center
notes: Boston offers bulk item pickup by request
commonMistakes: Don't leave at curb without scheduling

materials.name: Large / bulk items
instructions: Schedule bulk pickup through Boston 311 app or call 617-635-4900
Place at curb on scheduled day
notes: Boston Public Works handles bulk collection
commonMistakes: Don't leave at curb without scheduling pickup

materials.name: Chargers and cables
instructions: Take to Best Buy or Boston e-cycling event
Do NOT put in blue recycling bin
notes: Cables tangle in recycling machinery
commonMistakes: Never put cables in curbside recycling

materials.name: Smartphone / phone
instructions: Factory reset first
Trade in at carrier stores
Take to Best Buy for free recycling
notes: MA bans electronics from trash
commonMistakes: Don't forget to wipe personal data

materials.name: Fruit / fruit scraps
instructions: If enrolled in Project Oscar: place in compost bin
Otherwise: place in trash
Community composting sites also available
notes: Project Oscar is Boston's curbside composting pilot
commonMistakes: Don't put food waste in the blue recycling bin

materials.name: Vegetables / vegetable scraps
instructions: If enrolled in Project Oscar: place in compost bin
Otherwise: place in trash
notes: All vegetable scraps accepted in composting
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Meat and bones
instructions: Place in trash
Most composting programs in Boston do not accept meat
notes: Check with Project Oscar for specific accepted items
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Dairy products
instructions: Pour expired liquids down drain
Solid dairy in trash
Rinse and recycle containers in blue bin
notes: Container goes in recycling; contents go in trash
commonMistakes: Rinse the container before recycling it

materials.name: Coffee grounds / tea bags
instructions: If enrolled in Project Oscar: place in compost bin
Paper filters and paper tea bags accepted
Otherwise: place in trash or use community composting
notes: Coffee grounds are excellent for composting
commonMistakes: Check that tea bags are paper, not plastic mesh

materials.name: Pet waste
instructions: Bag and place in trash
notes: Pet waste contains harmful bacteria
commonMistakes: Never compost pet waste

materials.name: Wax paper / parchment paper
instructions: Place in trash
Not recyclable due to coating
notes: Wax/silicone coating prevents recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Mirrors
instructions: Wrap carefully and place in trash
notes: Metallic coating prevents glass recycling
commonMistakes: Never put mirrors in recycling

materials.name: Ceramics and pottery
instructions: Place in trash
notes: Ceramics contaminate glass recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Ink / toner cartridges
instructions: Return to Staples or Best Buy
Manufacturers offer mail-back programs
notes: Some stores give credit for returns
commonMistakes: Don't throw in trash

materials.name: Fluorescent tubes
instructions: Take to Boston HHW event or Home Depot/Lowe's
Handle carefully to avoid breakage
notes: Contains mercury
commonMistakes: Don't put in trash
Don't break them

materials.name: Tires
instructions: Take to tire retailer
notes: Most shops accept old tires when you buy new ones
commonMistakes: Don't dump illegally

materials.name: Toothbrush
instructions: Place in trash
notes: Mixed plastic; not recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Makeup / cosmetics
instructions: Most containers go in trash
Check brand take-back programs
notes: Small items fall through sorting screens
commonMistakes: Nail polish is hazardous

materials.name: Egg cartons
instructions: Paper/cardboard egg cartons: place in blue recycling bin
Styrofoam egg cartons: place in trash
notes: Only paper-based cartons are recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't recycle styrofoam egg cartons

materials.name: Metal lids and caps
instructions: Place loose metal lids inside a metal can and crimp shut
Place in blue recycling bin
notes: Small loose lids can fall through sorting screens
commonMistakes: Don't put loose small caps directly in bin

materials.name: Paper bags
instructions: Flatten and place in blue recycling bin
notes: Clean paper bags are recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't recycle paper bags soiled with food

materials.name: Wrapping paper
instructions: Most wrapping paper: trash (glitter, foil, or lamination)
Plain paper wrapping: can be recycled
notes: Scrunch test: if it stays scrunched it may be recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't assume all wrapping paper is recyclable

materials.name: Cleaning products / chemicals
instructions: Take to Boston HHW collection day
Empty containers of non-hazardous cleaners: rinse and recycle if rigid plastic
notes: Never mix chemicals
commonMistakes: Don't pour chemicals down drains

materials.name: Fast food wrappers
instructions: Food-soiled wrappers: trash
Clean paper wrappers: blue recycling bin
notes: Greasy paper is not recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't put greasy wrappers in recycling

materials.name: Shredded paper
instructions: Place in trash
Too small to sort at recycling facility
notes: Shredded paper clogs equipment
commonMistakes: Don't put shredded paper in blue bin

materials.name: Plastic wrap and film
instructions: Place in trash
Or take to grocery store film drop-off
notes: Film plastic jams recycling machinery
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling bin

materials.name: Bread and grains
instructions: If enrolled in Project Oscar: place in compost bin
Otherwise: place in trash
notes: Grain products accepted in composting programs
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Eggs / eggshells
instructions: If enrolled in Project Oscar: crush and place in compost bin
Otherwise: place in trash
notes: Eggshells add calcium to compost
commonMistakes: Crush for faster breakdown

compost: Food scraps (via curbside pilot or community composting)
trash: Plastic shopping bags (take to store drop-off)

recycle: Plastic shopping bags and black/white trash bags

tips: Blue bin single-stream recycling: metal, glass, plastic, paper all go together
Recycling must be in a lidded container (except eligible neighborhoods that can use heavy-duty clear bags)
Eligible clear-bag neighborhoods: Back Bay/Bay Village, Beacon Hill, Charlestown, Fenway, Mission Hill, North End, Roxbury, South Boston, South End, West End
Bins must be out by 6 AM on collection day
Project Oscar is Boston's curbside composting pilot for food scraps
No plastic shopping bags or black/white trash bags in recycling

locations.name: Boston Household Hazardous Waste Drop-off
locations.hours: Check boston.gov for scheduled HHW collection days
locations.notes: Boston holds periodic HHW collection events for residents. Call 311 for dates.

locations.name: Boston Public Works Drop-off Center
locations.notes: Boston residents can drop off select items. Call ahead to confirm.
